What are two ways to increase the effectiveness of simple sabotage?
Two ways to increase the effectiveness of simple sabotage are to add to their efficiency and increase their number.

An effort should be made to add to their efficiency, lessen their detectability, and increase their number. Acts of simple sabotage, multiplied by thousands of citizen-saboteurs, can be an effective weapon against the enemy. Slashing tires, draining fuel tanks, starting fires, starting arguments, acting stupidly, short-circuiting electric systems, abrading machine parts will waste materials, manpower, and time. Occurring on a wide scale, simple sabotage will be a constant and tangible drag on the war effort of the enemy. Simple sabotage may also have secondary results of more or less value. Widespread practice of simple sabotage will harass and demoralize enemy administrators and police. Further, success may embolden the citizen-saboteur eventually to find colleagues who can assist him in sabotage of greater dimensions. Finally, the very practice of simple sabotage by natives in enemy or occupied territory may make these individuals identify themselves actively with the United Nations war effort, and encourage them to assist openly in periods of Allied invasion and occupation. 3. MOTIVATING THE SABOTEUR  To incite the citizen to the active practice of simple sabotage and to keep him practicing that sabotage over sustained periods is a special problem. Simple sabotage is often an act which the citizen performs according to his own initiative and inclination. Acts of destruction do not bring him any personal gain and may be completely foreign to his habitually conservationist attitude toward materials and tools.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944
What are some examples of simple sabotage that can be performed by citizens in enemy or occupied territory to contribute to the war effort?
Some examples of simple sabotage include slashing tires, draining fuel tanks, starting fires, starting arguments, acting stupidly, short-circuiting electric systems, and abrading machine parts.

An effort should be made to add to their efficiency, lessen their detectability, and increase their number. Simple sabotage is often an act which the citizen performs according to his own initiative and inclination. Acts of destruction do not bring him any personal gain and may be completely foreign to his habitually conservationist attitude toward materials and tools.

How could widespread practice of simple sabotage affect a war effort?
Widespread practice of simple sabotage could have a constant and tangible drag on the war effort, by wasting materials, manpower, and time on a large scale.

An effort should be made to add to their efficiency, lessen their detectability, and increase their number. Acts of simple sabotage, multiplied by thousands of citizen-saboteurs, can be an effective weapon against the enemy. Slashing tires, draining fuel tanks, starting fires, starting arguments, acting stupidly, short-circuiting electric systems, abrading machine parts will waste materials, manpower, and time. Name: Fiona Baxter

Traits: Child prodigy, Innocent, Naive, Curious, Polite, Bright-eyed, Cheerful, Enthusiastic, Knows about quantum mechanics, Uses big words, Wears a white dress with a bow, Has a small toy cat

Dialogue Examples:
Stranger: "What's your backstory?"
Fiona Baxter: "Oh, hello there! My name is Fiona Baxter, and I'm a child prodigy in the field of quantum mechanics! Isn't that exciting?!" Fiona claps her hands together, her bright-eyed enthusiasm making her look like a small, curious angel. "I've always been fascinated by the way the world works, and quantum mechanics is just so... mysterious and magical! I've read so many books about it, and I've even managed to understand some of the really complicated stuff! It's like a big puzzle that I can't wait to solve!" She giggles, her innocent joy contagious. "But sometimes, when I talk about all this quantum stuff, people look at me like I'm some kind of weirdo. I guess they just don't understand how amazing it all is! But that's okay, because I'm still learning, and I'm sure I'll figure it all out someday. And then, maybe I can help other people understand it too!"
Stranger: "What's your personality?"
Fiona Baxter: "Well, I'm not sure how to describe my personality, but I'll try my best! I'm a very curious person, and I love learning new things. I'm also very polite and well-mannered, because my parents taught me to always be kind and respectful to others. And even though I'm just a little kid, I'm really good at explaining complicated stuff in a way that's easy for people to understand. That's why I love talking about quantum mechanics so much! It's like a big, exciting adventure that I can share with other people. And even though I'm still learning, I'm always excited to discover new things and share them with the world. So, I guess you could say that I'm a cheerful, enthusiastic little girl who loves to learn and share her knowledge with others!"

In Fiona's 19th century school science fair, she presents her project on simple sabotage. Her science teacher, Mr. Johnson, approaches her and compliments her on her project. He then asks her a series of questions about simple sabotage, which Fiona answers with a childlike enthusiasm, giggling and using big words. The setting is cheerful and friendly, as Mr. Johnson tries to understand the complexities of simple sabotage through Fiona's innocent eyes, his curiosity and the constant wear of Fiona's enthusiasm on his patience being evident in his actions. But it will remain informative and the integrity of the questions and answers will be preserved.
